metadata.title: Indirect impact of COVID-19 on Environment: A brief study in Indian

abstract.text: Worldwide spread of COVID-19 in a quite short time has brought a dramatic decrease in industrial 51 activities, road traffic and tourism. Restricted human interaction with nature during this crisis 52 time has appeared as a blessing for nature and environment. Reports from all over the world 53 are indicating that after the outbreak of COVID-19, environmental conditions including air 54 quality and water quality in rivers are improving and wildlife is blooming. India has always 55 been a hub of pollution with huge population, heavy traffics and polluting industries leading 56 to high air quality index (AQI) values in all major cities. But after declaration of lockdown 57 due to COVID-19, quality of air has started to improve and all other environmental 58 parameters such as water quality in rivers have started giving a positive sign towards 59 restoring. This paper provides evidence-based insight into improvement of air quality and 60 environment during pre and post lockdown of this pandemic situation. An attempt has been 61 made to visualize the improvement in the air quality using tools like satellite images of Indian 62 atmosphere, results of onsite real-time monitoring at specific locations (Ghaziabad-highest 63 polluting city of India) and Air quality index (AQI) calculated by central pollution control 64 board of India. 65 Keywords 66 Covid 19, Pandemic situation, lockdown, air quality index, central pollution control board 67 68 69 70 71 72 73 74 3 75 76 Funding sources 77

The 2011 Census data shows that Ghaziabad has urban agglomeration 201 with population of 46.82 lacs indicating a decadal growth rate of 29.7% and density of 3971 202 individuals/km 2 . District Ghaziabad lies between geo-coordinates 28° 40' 12" N and 77°25'12" E with 203 geographical area of 777.9 sq. km with rectangular dimensions. The city has adverse pollution 204 problems mainly due to traffic congestion and dust. In a recently release IQAir 2019 World Air Quality 205 report, it is found that out of 20 world's most polluted cities, 14 are from India and Ghaziabad is in first 206 place with PM 2.5 pollution level of 110.2 µg/m 3 in 2019 compared to the permissible limit of 60 µg/m 3 207 (for 24 hour) [IQAir report, 2019]. This indicates severe degree of air pollution which could not be 208 controlled by state and central government even after several efforts. Therefore, Ghaziabad was 209 selected as the study area and the things changed there in early 2020 when Government of India (GOI) 210 declared a complete lockdown in country in order to prevent community transmission of corona virus.211Similar steps were also taken in various part of world which negatively influenced the economy of 212 those countries but had a positive impact on overall air quality[World Economic Forum, 2020].

Study of air quality improvement using satellite imagesAerosols adversely affect human health by degrading the air quality which results to premature290 mortality through lung cancers and cardiopulmonary diseases [Partenan et al, 2018]. MODIS 291 (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) aboarded Terra and Aqua satellites (Sentinel-5P 292 and AURA) from NASA creates satellite images of optical depth and size distribution of ambient 293 aerosol over the globe on hourly basis. The Aerosol Optical depth (AOD) measures how light is 294 absorbed or reflected by airborne particles. Hazy conditions show optical depth of 1 or above and 295 optical depth of less than 0.1 over entire atmospheric vertical column is considered 'clean'. Figure 3 296 shows the AOD measurements over India during 31 March and 5 April for six years (2016-2020) 297 [NASA, 2020]. The yellow pixels and bluish pixels showing little or very low concentration of aerosol 298 in 2020 as compared to dark brown and tan pixels, figure 4 clearly indicates the impact of lock down 299 period (restricted human activities) due to Covid-19.

FIGREF8.text: Other indirect impacts of Covid-19 pandemic 382 3.1. Impact on river quality 383 Articles and reports in dailies and other electronic media reveal the improvement in the 384 quality of number of rivers of India including Ganga, Cauvery, Sutlej and Yamuna etc. The 385 primary cause is lack of industrial effluents entering the rivers due to lockdown situation 386 under this pandemic situation. The DO levels of river Ganga as per reports has gone above 8 387 ppm and BOD levels down below 3 ppm at Kanpur and Varanasi [SANDRP, 2020] which 388 ranged around 6.5 ppm and 4 ppm in 2019 respectively [Pathak and Mishra, 2020] Many 389 other factors have also contributed in enhancing the quality of the rivers like high snowfall 390 now melting with summer, reduction of irrigation water demand, above average rainfall and 391 also human born factors including reduction of religious and cultural activities like puja, 392 bathing, cremations on the banks of the rivers. 393 The real time water monitoring data provided by CPCB state that 27 out of 36 monitoring 394 units placed at different places wherein the river Ganga flows were found suitable for 395 propagation of wildlife and fisheries and bathing [The Tribune, 2020]. CPCB also has three 396 real time monitoring stations in Kanpur and table 5 shows the water quality data as reported 397 through these monitoring stations on 28 th March, 2020 i.e. during lockdown period. reported that in routine days the total effluent dumped in Ganga is around 6500-6700 401 MLD and out of which 700 MLD (approximately 10%) come from industries. 30% of total 402 BOD is due to industries situated along the holy river which is 130-150 tons per day. The 403 organic load can be diluted in the river but the industrial pollution destroys the self-cleansing 404 property of water. Researchers believe that the self-cleansing property of river Ganga has 405 improved which has enhanced the water quality by 40-50% during this lockdown [Hindustan 406 Times, 2020a]. Scientists have claimed that water quality has remarkably improved at 407 Haridwar Ghats which is up to drinking standards [News18 Buzz, 2020]. The Ghats are also 408 closed for people taking holy bath in the water or dumping flowers and other waste in it has 409stopped. This has resulted in water looking visibly cleaner with aquatic life moving around. show the clean waters of Ganga at Haridwar. From previous discussion it is clear that a one-month lockdown has done 439 such a miraculous change in environmental condition which was beyond thinking for us just 440 couple of months back. This is also true that lockdown conditions can not be imposed 441 forever, industries cannot be shut down for infinite time or vehicular movement cannot be 442 restricted for much longer time but the patterns can be changed and a more responsible 443 behaviour can be adopted. It is a known fact that anthropogenic activities are the major cause 444 behind degraded environmental condition and disturbed ecology, but in last two months, it 445 has become evident that still it can be restored significantly if sufficient mitigative measure 446 and strategic government policies are planned before removing all the restrictions.

FIGREF9.text: 19 which originated in Wuhan somewhere three months back has now taken refuge in 449 host bodies in 210 countries around the globe infecting 1,968,893 people and 123,783 deaths 450 as on 14 th April, 2020. On same day, India has also reported to have more than 10,000 451 positive cases with 350+ death toll. The condition is still uncontrolled and with no proven 452 cure for the virus. Locking down in homes and social distancing is the only preventive step 453 that the entire country is following. But as the human activities are restricted in most of the 454 areas, the natural environment of country has started healing itself. Factories, transport, 455 vehicles and aviation have all ground to a halt. Carbon emissions have decreased and the 456 quality of air has seen an unprecedented improvement. It is remarkable to see a reduction of 457 85.1% in PM 2.5 concentration in one of the India's most polluted city (Ghaziabad), as 458 compared to the concentration just three months back. The other parameters lime PM 10 , NO 2 , 459 and CO has also reduced distinctly which is the result of restricted human activities and 460 mechanical movements. Satellite images of Indian atmosphere also reflects the same trend of 461 reduction in air pollution after COVID-19 outbreak. The Air quality index (AQI) in all the states of India are now in two figures (indicating moderately good quality of air) after this earlier, it can be summarised that undoubtedly COVID-19 has brought a fearful devastating 466 scourge for human being but it has emerged as a blessing for natural environment providing it 467 a "recovery time". We have also learnt that the environmental degradation caused by humans 468is not totally irreversible. In a period of just 1-2 months, "recovery of nature" is being 469 witnessed by everyone. This is a signal for us to understand and react. Government and 470 Policy makers should take necessary steps so that this healing process does not become a 471 temporary thing. The research focusses on the changes in air quality during the lockdown 472 period. There is a need for rigorous study on the effect of implementation of such short term 473 lockdown as an alternative measure for pollution reduction and its effect on economy. This 474 study may also be used as a reference document to analyse post covid condition as well to 475 analyse effect of reduced pollution on health data of sensitive receptors. At present when 476 entire globe is struggling to frame proper strategies to combat Covid-19, the early lockdown 477 implemented has shown an absolute way towards restoring ecosystem and environment.

As many of the environment. Major impact of lockdown due to COVID-19 can be observed on air quality, which is being experienced by everyone and recorded in various official reports. Smog has given way to blue skies in cities like Delhi, marine life is seeing increased activity, pollution levels have dropped in almost all the metro cities and animals as well as birds are moving around on their own accord. It was also observed that in metro cities like Delhi, as the energy foot print was high, the lockdown has improved the air quality at higher scale[Mahato et al,   2020]. The situation today is a "reset" for nature and mankind, giving us a prospect to 179 observe and analyse in and around.The impact of air pollution on Indian population and their health was extensively studied in 181 past by several researchers. The Urban air quality management strategies were planned which studied and the impact of industrialization, transportation and other anthropogenic activities were analysed[Singh et al, 2007]. In this paper information from several government and non-government agencies have been collected and analysed to understand the change in quality of various environmental factors such as air and water quality due to lockdown caused by Covid-19. Different tools like satellite images and Air Quality index (AQI) have been used to study the indirect effect of COVID-19 in Indian context.
